Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Distributed Online Decision-Making in Large-Scale Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Decentralized architectures for decision-making are coming to the fore as more and more distributed infrastructures are deployed to address current challenges and needs of society, including "smart grids" for energy distribution, sensor and actuator networks for ecological monitoring and control, sustainable mass transportation systems, etc. The objective is to ensure that local actions at the nodes result in coherent collective behavior of the network. Systems of this type operate in highly uncertain environments that are noisy, unpredictable and possibly subject to adversarial disturbances. The goal of this research project is to develop a comprehensive theoretical and algorithmic framework for real-time adaptive decision-making in such large-scale systems under resource and cost constraints.

Online decision-making is concerned with real-time sequential planning in the presence of model uncertainty, nonstationarity, and possibly adversarial disturbances. The investigators study a novel extension of this paradigm to decentralized settings, where the actions have to be taken at the nodes of a large network, and the nodes only have access to noisy local information. The research entails explicit consideration of a temporally varying environment with a priori unknown dynamics; analysis and application in settings with significant model uncertainty, potential unmodeled statistical dependencies in observations either across the network nodes or over time, and possible adversarial contamination of data; and accounting for the influence of the decisions and network actions on the surrounding environment. The theoretical component of the project captures the impact of decentralization on the quality of the decision-making; the algorithmic component is to develop, analyze, and implement algorithms that come as close as possible to the derived theoretical bounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this project comprises fundamental performance bounds and efficient algorithms for distributed online decision-making in large-scale networks. Online decision-making is an emerging paradigm at the intersection of optimization, machine learning and control which is concerned with real-time sequential planning of actions or decisions in the presence of model uncertainty, nonstationarity, and possibly adversarial disturbances.


The project has contributed a new theoretical and algorithmic framework for distributed online decision-making, where the actions have to be taken at the nodes of a large network and the costs depend on the individual node actions and on the state of the entire network. This general framework is applicable to emerging problems in efficient real-time control of large-scale distributed infrastructures, where centralized decision-making is costly or difficult. 


Research performed as part of this project has demonstrated that, using ideas from Markov chain theory, statistical physics, information theory, and convex analysis, it is possible to develop efficient and scalable algorithms for decentralized online decision-making and control in large-scale networks even in the presence of nonstationarity and model uncertainty. The resulting algorithms enjoy favorable scaling of the regret with both the time horizon (often matching or nearly matching the corresponding scaling of the best centralized algorithms) and the network parameters (such as number of nodes, maximal degree, and the spectral gap of the natural random walk on the network). In particular, it was demonstrated that, under mild assumptions on the communication capabilities of the nodes and on the underlying information structure, the regret scales as a low-degree polynomial of the network size. These results apply to time-invariant and time-varying networks, under mild connectivity assumptions that are standard in the literature on distributed information processing.


Complementing the above results that demonstrate what can be achieved, a rigorous information-theoretic analysis has provided insight into the fundamental limitations of any scheme for distributed information processing and decision-making. These fundamental limitations are determined by the interplay of the following characteristics: the sensitivity of the overall objectives to local estimation and computation errors; the network topology; and the information capacities of the communication links connecting the agents. The regret guarantees of the algorithms developed as part of the project achieve these information-theoretic limits or closely approach them.

In terms of its broader impact, this project has resulted in potentially fundamental contributions to large-scale optimization, decision-making, and control applications in distributed sustainable infrastructures which are currently developed and deployed to address the society’s technological and scientific needs. All of the theoretical, methodological, and algorithmic outcomes of the project have been widely disseminated via journal publications and participation in international and domestic conferences.
